comment.author: 34143061@N03
comment._content:
I think it is lovely. Keep in mind, in Victorian times such photos were common. It often times was the only way to have a photo of someone since not everyone made arrangements for a portrait before their death. This man seems to have died fairly  young, and they wanted to remember him at that moment, and to express their love and grief.  I see nothing whatsoever, wrong with it.

They did not have snapshots, home movies, etc. as we do now. Most of us have photos of our loved ones, and most people are comforted looking at those when they miss someone.  I wish people didn't make fun of this poor family who didn't expect to end up with their pic seen by the world.

comment._content:
This shows that images were manipulated even when photography was young(ish).  A white blouse contained in a black region - her jacket - is ideal for a second exposure before developing.

The question is the motive; to sucker the gulible or maybe as a symbolic gesture of love for the deceased - if this is his image...
